issue.title: It should be possible to interact/comment on each job

milestone.title: Job Board Reboot
milestone.description:
We have a barely functioning (but has had some success) job board. We have lots of issues & ideas of how to improve it, let's try to get a lot of these hammered out and implemented sooner rather than later. 

I'm setting a goal to achieve this for OSCAL 2017

issue.body:
Some big problems with the job board at the moment are:

- it’s very static, discussion is difficult to start
- you don’t know the state of it, if it’s taken already
- we don’t know if it’s done

As far as I know it’s possible to embed Discourse thread replies in a website. We could have a category in the Discourse called »Jobs« (you can’t create posts but will be led to the [job submission form](http://opensourcedesign.net/jobs/job-form/)), and one thread per job. Then on every job there’s the discussion thread below.
@erlend-sh could you point us how to do that maybe? :)

We do have to require that the people have to register at Discourse though and be subscribed to the issue. But maybe that can be automated and will lead to growth.

cc @jdittrich @simonv3 @belenbarrospena @janushead @guiguru @HeikoTietze @bnvk @evalica

comment.body: I think so? I mean, by no means am I an expert on this.

comment.body: So we could have a unified feed and then a "category" attribute which would tell Discourse where to add the topic?

issue.title: It should be possible to interact/comment on each job

milestone.title: Job Board Reboot
milestone.description:
We have a barely functioning (but has had some success) job board. We have lots of issues & ideas of how to improve it, let's try to get a lot of these hammered out and implemented sooner rather than later.

comment.body:
Looks like a limitation on the Discourse side. There's only one input field for where to fetch RSS feed data from and it seems to apply to all embedded Discourse threads.

If we have separate repos we can't do this I think, but isn't it also fairly standard to provide an RSS feed of all updates from a site?

> we can only do it for jobs I think, not for, say, articles

Why is this? We can (and should / am working towards) have multiple RSS feeds.

issue.title: Replace hardcoded URLs to site in pages and templates
issue.body:
Currently, in throughout the website Jekyll templates and pages, the website URL

```
http://opensourcedesign.net
```

Is hardcoded. We should make use of Jekyll variables, so as to make developing locally, a stagging server, etc... all work well. Thus, we should replace that value with 

```
{{ site.url }}
```

Which then gets drawn from [_config.yml](https://github.com/opensourcedesign/opensourcedesign.github.io/blob/master/_config.yml) values.

comment.body:
yeah, the ID issue probably happened because I have since deleted and created that thing a couple of times for testing purposes. 

This is actually pretty incredible functionality from Discourse. We can set it so that stuff gets automatically gets created when Discourse polls the feed.xml for the jobs (in which case we can only do it for jobs I think, not for, say, articles), or that it gets created when someone views the page (as is the case now). 

As some of the old projects gets viewed this might take some curation on the forum, hiding posts etc.

issue.title: Styling on job form thank you page is broken
issue.body:
Probably because the bootstrap stuff was moved recently?

http://opensourcedesign.net/jobs/thank-you/

https://github.com/opensourcedesign/jobs/blob/master/thankyou.html

comment.body: ah cool! possibly because it was moved over from a stand-alone repo.

Merge pull request #149 from SuperHaker/master

Added amrit-singh in people

issue.title: Specify certain pages as "Uneditable"
issue.body:
With the integration of the edit page buttons (as seen here), which is now on each page...

![osd-edit-source-links-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/48677/31679068-501341f8-b370-11e7-8b20-62fd4bbae3de.png)

...certain pages probably should not be editable via the [Prose editor](https://edit.opensourcedesign.net) as they will have HTML, Jekyll logic, and can seriously break the site if they are edited wrong. Some examples of these pages are:

- 404.html
- index.html
- articles.html

This should be simple enough by adding the file to the Prose config excludes, and then a Jekyll var in each page, that either displays or hides the `Edit this page` link.

comment.body: @evalica sure, I don't see a strong argument for or against CSS class vs. just not displaying the HTML in the template. Regardless, we need to add value to FrontMatter of "uneditable" pages.

comment.body:
w00t w00t, great @simonv3 great step and progress 👍 

For some reason I had to update the ID in your link to Discourse from 328 to 353, not sure why.

How does this currently get created? Is it 100% automated? Is that perhaps why the ID issue happened?

issue.title: Add link to people form somewhere on the site
issue.body:
Right now the [people form](http://opensourcedesign.net/people-form/) exists, but it's not findable. We should let people find it. Where does it make sense to add?

I think overall it would make sense in a "Are you a designer" section, but we'd need one like that.

https://github.com/opensourcedesign/organization/pull/100

cc @evalica

comment.body: I think this should be a "call to action" as part of something like **Join Us** or **Participate** which also plays into the [contribute page](https://opensourcedesign.net/contribute/) which I also think needs some love and to be more featured. I have some ideas, but those of others are much appreciated :)

issue.title: Styling on job form thank you page is broken
issue.body:
Probably because the bootstrap stuff was moved recently?

http://opensourcedesign.net/jobs/thank-you/

https://github.com/opensourcedesign/jobs/blob/master/thankyou.html

comment.body: Was because that file (for some inexplicable reason) did *not* have the `layout: default` value decalred in Front-Matter and instead had the whole HTML page...

Okay! This has been implemented but it can use a _lot_ of improvement. 

I think a lot of that improvement will come from figuring out the formatting and the markdown, eg.:

https://discourse.opensourcedesign.net/t/jobs-libreoffice-mascot/328

http://opensourcedesign.net/jobs/jobs/2017-06-28-libreoffice-mascot

Yay \o/

cc @bnvk @jancborchardt @evalica
